subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] I need clarification on British pronunciations.
msgSnippet: It would be more correct to say that some R s were dropped in Read s dialect. Here are a few resources:
messageBody:
It would be more correct to say that some 'R's were dropped in Read's dialect. Here are a few resources:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhotic_and_non-rhotic_accents

 

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Received_Pronunciation

  I won't comment further on that, as I'm no expert.


   In my dialect of American English (mostly midwestern with some southern), hole and whole are identical in pronunciation - but hull contains a lax vowel, more like 'uh' than 'oh'.

   I am unable to reliably detect many of the differences discussed in Read's work and in this forum, but don't consider that too much of a handicap. The members here are quite accepting of these differences as Read himself was. His decision to always use the 'r' symbol (whether the writer pronounced it or not) was to prevent excluding many of his countrymen from his invention.
